translated: The Sutra on the Buddha's Teaching for Eliminating Disasters in One Fascicle
Translated by Zhi Qian, an upÄsaka from Yuezhi in the Wu Dynasty
Thus have I heard: Once the Buddha was in the country of Shravasti. At that time, there was a county where everyone practiced
the Buddha's five precepts and ten wholesome deeds, and no one in the county brewed alcohol.
There was a son of a wealthy family who wanted to go on a long business trip. Before leaving, his parents told their son:
You should diligently uphold the five precepts, practice the ten wholesome deeds, and be careful not to drink alcohol and violate the Buddha's grave precepts.
He accepted the teachings and set off.
When he arrived in another country, he saw his old classmates and close friends, and they were delighted to see each other.
They took him home and brought out grape wine, wanting to drink together.
He declined, saying:
In my country, we uphold the Buddha's five precepts and no one dares to violate them.
If one drinks alcohol, one will be born as a foolish person in the next life and will not have the opportunity to see the Buddha.
Moreover, when leaving one's parents, if the parents admonish each other, and with wine and food one still disobeys and violates the precepts, there is no greater offense.
Although the mind is delighted to meet with acquaintances after a long separation, it is not appropriate to cause me to violate the precepts and disobey my parents' teachings.
The host said:
You and I have the same teacher, and in terms of kindness we are brothers. My parents are your parents, and they respect each other. How can I disobey them?
If I were in your home, I would certainly follow your parents.
Unable to refuse, he then agreed to drink.
He lay drunk for three days. When he woke up, he felt remorse and fear.
After the matter was finished, he returned home and confessed to his parents. His parents said:
You disobeyed our teachings and furthermore violated the precepts. The gradual confusion of the Dharma is not the way of a filial son.
Do not speak of it. Be a model for the country.
He then expelled him from the country, saying he should not stay here.
The son, because of violating the precepts, was expelled by his relatives, and went to another country, staying in a guest house.
The host served three ghosts and spirits who could transform into human form, appearing in front of him, eating and drinking, and speaking with people.
The host served them for many years, exhausting his wealth, and his family suffered from illness and death without end. Disgusted with the ghosts, they discussed it in private.
The ghosts knew that the people were suffering and afflicted, and the ghosts discussed among themselves:
This person's wealth is exhausted, and it is all because of us. We have never benefited him, causing him to be disgusted with us.
We should seek precious treasures to give to him, to please his mind!
They then went to steal the king's treasury from another country and piled up the treasures in the garden, saying:
You have served us for many years, and the hardship has been great. Now we want to bless you and make you wealthy. Isn't this wonderful?
The host said:
I receive the great god's grace.
The ghost said:
In your garden there is gold and silver, you can go and take it, then you will have great blessings and fulfill your wishes.
The host joyfully entered the garden, saw the extraordinary objects, carried them back home, and thanked the ghost for its kindness:
Tomorrow I want to prepare food and drink, I hope you will deign to come.
He set out delicacies and everything was ready. The ghost came to the door, saw the man from ÅšrÄvastÄ« in the host's house, and ran away.
The host chased after him and invited him back:
Now the humble offerings are all ready, since the great god has already deigned to come, why do you leave?
The ghost said:
There is a distinguished guest in your house, how can I go forward?
He was startled and ran away again.
The host returned home and sat thinking to himself:
There is no other person in my house, only this man!
He went out and said, respectfully offering everything, and they enjoyed each other's company.
After they had finished eating and drinking, he asked him:
What merits do you have in the world that this deity I serve fears your son and flees?
The guest fully explained the Buddha's merits, the five precepts, and the ten wholesome deeds;

he had indeed violated the precept against drinking and was expelled by his relatives, but he still had the remaining four precepts, so he was protected by the heavenly deity, and the deity did not dare to confront him.
The host said:
Although I serve this deity, I have long been disgusted with it. Now I wish to uphold the Buddha's five precepts.
He then received the three refuges, five precepts, and ten wholesome deeds from the guest, and single-mindedly diligently practiced them, not daring to be lazy.
He asked where the Buddha was, and if he could see him.

The host single-mindedly went there and passed through a pavilion.
In the middle, there was an upright woman who was the wife of a man-eating ghost.
The man was traveling a long way, and the day was drawing to a close. He asked a woman to stay the night, but she replied:
Be careful not to stay here, you should go on quickly.
The man asked:
For what reason do you say this? Do you have some intention?
The woman replied:
I have already told you, why ask again?
The man thought to himself:
The people of ÅšrÄvastÄ« in the past, who fully observed the four precepts, even my spirit was still afraid of them to such an extent.
I have already received the three refuges, the five precepts, and the ten wholesome [deeds], my mind is not lax, so what am I afraid of?
He then stayed the night.
The man-eating ghost saw the awe-inspiring power of the man's observance of the precepts, and hovered around him, not returning to the inn for a night.
The next day, the man continued on his way and saw the scattered bones of people devoured by ghosts, his hair stood on end, his heart was frightened and regretful, and he thought to himself:

In my home country, my family's living conditions were very comfortable, but I was deceived by this person, who said the Buddha was in Shravasti, and that it was not wonderful, but instead saw scattered bones everywhere.
Evil thoughts arose again, and he thought to himself:
It would be better to return to that woman and go back to my home country to live together as before, wouldn't that be happy?
He immediately turned back and returned to the inn, and followed the woman again, asking to stay overnight.
The woman said to the man:
Why have you come back again?
He replied:
My plans did not work out, so I came back. I want to stay overnight again.
The woman said:
You are dead!
My husband is a man-eating ghost, and he will be back soon. You should leave quickly!

This man did not believe, so he stayed and did not leave. His mind became even more confused, and lustful thoughts arose again. He no longer believed in the virtue of the Buddha's three refuges or the intention of the five precepts and ten wholesome [actions]. The celestial spirit then left and no longer protected him.
The ghost was able to return. The woman feared the ghost would eat the man, so she pitifully hid him in a jar.
The ghost smelled the human scent and said to the wife:
Did you get some meat?
I want to eat it.
The wife said:
I didn't go out, how could I get meat?
The wife asked the ghost:
Why didn't you return last night?
The ghost said:
It's because you abandoned the honored guest and made me be driven out.
The man in the jar became even more terrified and no longer recognized the intention of the three refuges.
The wife said:
Why can't you get meat?
The ghost said:
It is because of your Buddha's disciples that the celestial spirits have driven me out to sleep in the open for forty miles. I am still frightened and uneasy, so I cannot get any meat.
When his wife heard this, she silently rejoiced and asked her husband:
What are the Buddha's precepts that you all uphold?
The ghost said:
I am extremely hungry. Quickly bring me some meat. Don't ask about this.
These are the unsurpassed true precepts. I dare not speak of them.
The wife said:
Speak of them, and I will give you some meat.
The ghost's kind was greedy and unrestrained, wanting to eat without stopping. The wife pressed him to ask about it, so he then spoke the three refuges and the five grave precepts:
First, be kind and do not kill;
Second, have pure faith and do not steal;
Third, be chaste and do not engage in sexual misconduct;
Fourth, do not speak falsely with the mouth;
Fifth, be filial and obedient and do not get drunk.

When the ghost first spoke one precept, the wife immediately accepted it. She held the five precepts in her mind and recited them orally. The man recognized the five precepts in the jar and followed them.
Indra knew that the minds of these two people had taken refuge in the Buddha, so he selected fifty good spirits to protect the two people, and the ghost then ran away.
The next day, the wife asked the man:
Were you afraid?
He replied:
Very afraid!
I am grateful for your kindness, and my mind awakened and recognized the Buddha.
The wife said to the man:
Why did you turn back yesterday?
He replied:
I saw the scattered bones of a newly deceased person, and I was afraid, so I turned back.
The wife said:
Those bones are what I discarded.
I was originally the daughter of a good family, but I was abducted by a ghost and taken as his wife. I was miserable and had nowhere to turn.
Now, thanks to your kindness, I have heard the Buddha's precepts and can leave this ghost.
The wife said:
Virtuous one, where do you wish to go now?
The man replied:
I wish to go to the country of Shravasti to see the Buddha.
The woman said:
Excellent!
I will leave my homeland and parents and follow the virtuous one to see the Buddha.

they asked:
Virtuous ones!
Where have you come from and where do you wish to go?
They replied:
We have come from the Buddha.
They asked:
You have already seen the Buddha, why are you leaving again?
They replied:
The Buddha spoke the sutra today, but our minds are still confused and we still do not understand, so we are returning to our homeland.

The two virtuous ones explained the details, and because ghosts fear those who uphold the precepts and practice diligently, their minds opened up and they were enlightened, and they all returned to see the Buddha.
The Buddha saw them from afar and smiled, and five-colored light emerged from his mouth.

The Buddha said:
These 498 people have now found their original teacher and come to see the Buddha. They will all attain the Way.

The 500 people came before the Buddha, bowed to the Buddha, and listened to the sutra with single-minded attention. Their minds opened up and their intentions were resolved. They all became monks and attained the Way of the Arhat.
The Buddha said:
The one who violated the precept against drinking alcohol is the innkeeper, who has been the woman's brother for many lifetimes;
but these two were the teachers of the 498 people in their past lives.
People in the world who seek the Way must find their original teacher and good friends before they can understand.
